taxonConcepts.nameAccordingTo: Species 2000 & ITIS Catalogue of Life: April 2013

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObjects.title: Biology
dataObjects.description: Occurs in swamps, heavily vegetated sloughs and small sluggish streams, usually over mud.  Oviparous, eggs are deposited in aquatic vegetation, preferably on strands of Ceratophyllum sp. when available (Ref. 58020).

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObjects.description: North America:  Lower Altamaha River drainage, Georgia south to central part of peninsular Florida, and west to Choctawhatchee River drainage, Florida, USA.
dataObjects.references: Gilbert, C.R. 2004 Family Elassomatidae Jordan 1877. Pygmy sunfishes. Calif. Acad. Sci. Annotated Checklists of Fishes (33):5. (Ref. 51664)

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObjects.description: Southeastern U.S.A.: Lower Altamaha River drainage, Georgia, south to central part of peninsular Florida, and west to Choctawhatchee River drainage, Florida.

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Size
dataObjects.title: Max. size
dataObjects.references: Page, L.M. and B.M. Burr 1991 A field guide to freshwater fishes of North America north of Mexico. Houghton Mifflin Company, Boston. 432 p. (Ref. 5723)

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObjects.title: Environment
dataObjects.description: demersal; freshwater; pH range: 6.0; dH range: 5

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LifeCycle
dataObjects.description: The fish scatter their eggs into thick plant vegetation.

dataObjects.subject: http://www.eol.org/voc/table_of_contents#Taxonomy
dataObjects.description: Comments: MtDNA data indicate that Elassoma is monophyletic; see Quattro et al. (2001) for information on phylogenetic relationships among the six species in this genus (E. alabamae is widely divergent; E. boehlkei and E. okatie are sister taxa related to the widespread E. evergladei).
